items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In accordance with California Education Code Section 72023.5, which sets forth a requirement that the governing board review the privileges granted to student trustees by May 15 each year, the district's board policy regarding student members of the governing board (BP 2015) was presented for review at the regular meeting on April 7, 2014. The governing board currently grants student trustees the privilege to cast an advisory vote, make and second motions, and to receive compensation.  
	 
References:
Education Code Section 72023.5 
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, extension 6104
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees readopt board policy 2015 Student Members.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2430 (formerly 2210) concerning concerning the governing board's delegation of authority to the Chancellor was presented for review and first reading at the regular meeting of April 7, 2014, and is now presented for adoption. The recommended revisions are suggested as good practice in order to meet accreditation standards and also bring the policy into alignment with the language and numbering system of the Community College League of California's (CCLC) Policy and Procedure Service. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, and deleted text is represented by strikethrough. 
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the revised board policy electronically by consensus on October 18, 2013. 
	 
References:
Educations Code Sections 70902(d) and 72400
Accreditation Standards IV.B.1.j, IV.B.2, and IV.B.3
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt revised board policy 2430 Delegation of Authority to Chancellor.
items.item_text: Board Policy 2430 (formerly 2210) Delegation of Authority to Chancellor - Revised (Second Reading)
items.item_text_raw: 2. Board Policy 2430 (formerly 2210) Delegation of Authority to Chancellor - Revised (Second Reading)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2432 (formerly 2212) concerning the district's designated line of authority in the chancellor's absence was presented for first reading on April 7, 2014, and is now submitted for approval. The revisions add language considered good practice concerning the governing board's authority to appoint an acting Chancellor in the event of an extended absence, change the policy number to mirror the Community College League of California's Policy and Procedure Service numbering system, and add legal references. New language is indicated on the attached by bold, underlined text.
	 
The revised policy was approved electronically by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on October 18, 2013.
	 
References:
Educations Code Sections 70902(d) and 72400
Title 5 Section 53021(b)
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt revised board policy 2432 Acting Chancellor in Absence of Chancellor.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The board policies listed below were proposed for retirement at the April 7, 2014, regular meeting.  The policies have not been reviewed in many years and are not among those recommended by the Community College League of California as legally required, legally advised, or good practice.
‪BP 1110 Communication with Public ‬
‪BP 1160 Catalogs‬
‪BP 1170 Participation of Citizens' Committees
‪BP 1180 Staff Participation in Community Activities‬
‪BP 1200 Public Performances by Students‬
‪BP 1210 Contests for Students‬
‪BP 1220 Use of Students as Volunteers in Community Services Projects‬
BP 2211 Chancellor as Secretary to the Board (duplicates language in BP 2210 Chancellor as Executive Officer of the Board) 
BP 2310 Treatment of Outside Reports
BP 2410 Administrative Procedure When Commendation or Criticism of Staff Members Received
BP 2610 Communication between Staff and Board
BP 6141 Public Domain
BP 9600 Flags at Half Staff
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the retirement of board policies 1110, 1170, 1180, 2211, 2310, 2410, 2610, and 9600 electronically on October 18, 2013; the retirement of board policies 1160, 1200, 1210, and 1220 at the November 15, 2014, meeting; and the retirement of board policy 6141 at the January 17, 2014, meeting.  
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends repeal of board policies 1110 Communication with Public, 1160 Catalogs, 1170 Participation of Citizens' Committees, 1180 Staff Participation in Community Activities, 1200 Public Performances by Students, 1210 Contests for Students, 1220 Use of Students as Volunteers in Community Services Projects, 2211 Chancellor as Secretary to the Board, 2310 Treatment of Outside Reports, 2410 Administrative Procedure When Commendation or Criticism of Staff Members Received, 2610 Communication between Staff and Board, 6141 Public Domain, and 9600 Flags at Half Staff.
items.item_text: Board Policies Proposed for Retirement (Second Reading)
items.item_text_raw: 4. Board Policies Proposed for Retirement (Second Reading)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has four vehicles, one forklift and three riding mowers that have been replaced (see attached Surplus Forms, 8 pages). The Associate Director of Facilities and Operations has determined that the vehicles, forklift and landscaping equipment are of no further use to the District. The estimated aggregate market value of the vehicles, forklift and landscaping equipment is greater than $5,000.00.  
	 
In accordance with Education Code section 81450, the Board must sell the property to the highest responsible bidder or reject all bids. The code also requires the sale to be posted in at least three public places in the district for not less than two weeks. 
	 
Purchasing Services will contract with Interschola, LLC to conduct an online auction that is open to the public. Proceeds will be deposited into the District General Fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, to sell the vehicles, forklift and landscaping equipment to the highest responsible bidder in accordance with Education Code Section 81450.
items.item_text: Sale of Surplus Vehicles, Material Handling and Landscaping Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 8. Sale of Surplus Vehicles, Material Handling and Landscaping Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has 17 pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (See attached Surplus Forms, 20 pages).  The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff 
has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value 
of this electronic equipment is greater than $5,000.00.
California Education Code 81450 provides the governing board of any community college district may sell for cash any personal property belonging to the district if the property is not required for school purposes, or 
if it should be disposed of for the purpose of replacement, or if it is unsatisfactory or not suitable for school use. The code also requires the sale to be posted in at least three public places in the district for not less than 
two weeks. The board shall sell the property to the highest responsible bidder or reject all bids.
Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited into the District’s general fund.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Authorize Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81450.
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 9. Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
1) New Student and Parent Open House
This major annual event welcomes prospective new students and their families to the college to engage with numerous faculty and staff representatives, tour the campus and take placement tests. This year, students will be provided opportunities to fulfill priority enrollment criteria through not only taking placement tests but also completing orientation. The Open House will be held from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. on Saturday, May 10.
	 
De Anza College President Brian Murphy requests a campus-wide waiver of parking fees until 3 p.m. on that day.
	 
 2) Vintage Mustang of America Car Show
The Automotive Technology Club of De Anza College has hosted the Vintage Mustang of America (VMOA) car show for the last ten years, featuring more than 200 cars, vendors and exhibits. It is one of the largest fundraising events and community outreach efforts on behalf of the club. The 37th annual car show will take place in Parking Lot A from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Saturday, June 21.
	 
De Anza College President Brian Murphy requests a waiver of parking fees in Parking Lot A until 5 p.m. on that day in order to accommodate the show. Attendees will pay the regular parking fee.
	 
Submitted by:
 Brian Murphy, President, De Anza College, ext. 8706
Additional contact names:
 Rob Mieso, Outreach, ext. 8835; Randy Bryant, Automotive Technology, ext. 8840
Is backup provided?
 No
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President Brian Murphy requests the Board of Trustees waive parking fees for two upcoming community events at De Anza College on May 10 and June 21, 2014.

Approval is sought for renewal of the Whittier Center and Alfred WAC facilities for the 2014-15 District’s HOPE program. 
	 
The renewal is in accordance with the attached “Agreement for the Use of Facilities Owned or Leased by Hope Services” effective July 1, 2014, through June 30, 2015.
	 
The original Hope lease was entered into on July 1, 2007, for a one-year period. Section three of this agreement stated “This agreement may be extended for additional one-year terms by the mutual written consent of the parties”.
	 
The lease amount remains the same as the previous year: $7,634/month ($91,608/year).

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The De Anza Associated Student Body Senate deliberated during the fall and winter quarters, holding its first vote to approve the budget on February 12, 2014.  On February 19, 2014, the DASB Senate held its confirming vote and approved the 2014â2015 DASB operating budget.  The Student Senators should be commended for recognizing their responsibility of allocating funds in a manner that benefits the students, academic programs and activities.  Once again for this fiscal year the Senate was able to creatively increase its income in order to support diminished college budgets.  These funds were allocated using strict budgetary goals that serve the most vital college and student needs.
	 
Submitted by:
Brian Murphy
Additional contact names:
Stacey Cook

Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On March 20, 2014, the Associated Students of Foothill College (ASFC) Campus Council approved the budget for the fiscal year 2014-2015. 
The goal of ASFC is to allocate funds intelligently and thoughtfully so that Foothill College students receive quality services, support programs and have the opportunity to participate in engaging events. We hope that our efforts translate into the cultivation of a welcoming atmosphere and a positive learning environment. The allocation of funds was discussed with these goals in mind. Additionally, we were able to access and spend down a portion of our Fund Balance.
	 
The manner in which ASFC provides funding to the campus community is based on our mission-based vision & goals, which are approved and adopted by members of ASFC every year. Our deliberation process began much earlier than previous years. We wanted to ensure that every decision we made was in accordance with our mission-based vision and goals so we began our process in early Fall. The budget development process went smoothly thanks to the collaborative work done by the budget team. 
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner
Additional contact names:
Daphne Small
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Foothill College President Judy Miner recommends that the Board of Trustee approves the ASFC budget for the fiscal year 2014-2015.
items.item_text: Approval of Associated Students of Foothill College (ASFC) Budget, 2014-2015 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Board Resolution No. 2006-23 was adopted in August 2006 to form a Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee for Measure C and approve the Oversight Committee Bylaws that have guided the committee to date.  
	 
In December 2013, there was a modification to Paragraph 5.4 of the Bylaws due to a recent change to Education Code section 15282, to allow members to serve for up to three (3) consecutive terms.
	 
The Board Resolution No. 2014-13 presented herein is to amend and restate the Bylaws to reflect additional recent changes to Education Code section 15282.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
As required by the deed that conveyed Parcel C at the former Onizuka Air Force Station in Sunnyvale to Foothill-De Anza Community College District, an annual utilization report was provided to the Department of Education on February 5, 2014. 
	 
On February 12, 2014, the Department of Education acknowledged receipt of the annual report.  After their review of the report, and in particular after their review of the Facilities and Site Leases that we have executed with CW Driver for demolition and construction of the new facility, the Department of Education has requested that both Foothill–De Anza Community College District and C.W. Driver execute the attached Consent to Lease Agreement for both the Facilities and Site Leases to require that applicable terms and conditions of the Quitclaim Deed are appropriately passed thru to CW Driver in the Facilities and Site Leases.  C.W. Driver has indicated their approval and is prepared to execute the attached agreement.
	 
The attached Consent to Lease Agreement is provided for Board approval.  
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director 
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Project Director, Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approval of the attached Consent to Lease Agreement with the Department of Education and CW Driver.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The boiler that provides heating to several buildings on the De Anza College campus, including the Campus Center, Visual and Performing Arts Center, Advanced Technology Center, and Student Community Service building does not function.  A temporary boiler was installed last October to provide heat during the winter months.  This project will replace the boiler system that feeds those buildings.
	 
The scope of work in this project will require the contractor to demolish the existing boiler and insall two replacement boilers and all necessary piping, valves, electrical power and wiring, and new boiler controls to make a completely functioning heating hot water system.  Additionally, the contractor will clean and flush out the system.  Funding permitted, alternate items would also require the contractor to remove and replace three heating hot water pumps that feed into the boiler and add metering controls and sensors to the boilers that track distributed energy usage at each building.
	 
Salas O’Brien prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid #1676 was legally advertised on March 21 and March 28, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the Daily Pacific Builder, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on April 16, 2014 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
CONTRACTOR
BASE BID AMOUNT
Alternate #1 – heating hot water pumps
Alternate #2 – metering controls
O. C. McDonald Co., Inc.
$302,270
$94,430
$ 7,250
Pullman Construction
$350,150
$36,845
$ 8,150
Environmental Systems Inc. of Northern California
$355,000
$79,530
$ 8,733
Integra Construction Services Inc.
$395,500
$37,500
$14,000
N. V. Heathorn Co.
$434,357
$87,953
$17,839
	 
The bid documents indicated the lowest bidder would be determined in accordance with Public Contract Code (PCC) 20103.8 (a) which states:
 (a) The lowest bid shall be the lowest bid price on the base contract without consideration of the prices on the additive or deductive items.
	 
Therefore, the lowest responsive and responsible bidder is O. C. McDonald Co., Inc.  O.C. McDonald has successfully completed several projects for the District and also worked on the ATC renovation project.
	 
The price of $302,270 for the base bid amount and $7,250 for Alternate #2 as submitted by O. C. McDonald Co., Inc. is within the construction budget of $320,000.   The project will be constructed with Plant Services Capital funding.
	 
Submitted by:
 Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
 Charles Allen, Lester Lyons, Tom Armstrong, Gina Bailey
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Director of Purchasing Services, Pam Grey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid #1668 – ATC Boiler Replacement, in the aggregate amount of $309,520 for the Base Bid Amount and Alternate #2 to O.C. McDonald Co., Inc.

items.item_text_raw: 26. Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1668 – ATC Boiler Replacement at De Anza College (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College and De Anza College have standardized on Krueger International faculty office furniture and classroom furniture.  The colleges have identified specific furniture performance criteria and service specifications that addressed concerns regarding flexibility, function, durability, quality, safety, comfort, and aesthetics.  
	 
The colleges expect to make several Measure C and Non-Measure C funded purchases of Krueger International furniture during the next two years. Because the estimated cost of the furniture will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $84,100, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”. The competitively bid Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) contract with Kruger International is available and it includes the items required by the colleges. 
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the FCCC contract for the same goods and services. The FCCC contract establish discounts for furniture inclusive of specification development services, space planning services, installation drawings, shipping and delivery costs, a 15-year parts and labor warranty, and installation services. 
	 
In addition, Krueger International makes a donation of one percent for all purchases to the California Community Colleges Scholarship Endowment.  All donations that result from the District’s purchases will be allocated to the District’s account and the resulting scholarships will go to the Foothill-De Anza students.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, x6166
Additional contact names:
Bernata Slater, Donna Jones Dulin, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for furniture and related services in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and the Foundation for California Community Colleges Contract #CB-13-013.
items.item_text: Authorize the use of Foundation for California Community Colleges contract to purchase furniture and related services from Krueger International pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 30. Authorize the use of Foundation for California Community Colleges contract to purchase furniture and related services from Krueger International pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill, District/Central Services and De Anza College.  
	 
De Anza Budget Transfer #43 includes the following actions:
Transfer $45.66 project savings from Project 203, Baldwin Winery & East Cottage “Historic Renovation” to Project 206, Stadium and Track to fund the project. Project 203 is financially closed.
Transfer $1,001.98 project savings from Project 247, G-Building to Project 206, Stadium and Track to fund the project. Project 247 is financially closed. 
Transfer $30,000 project savings from Project 274, Combined Site Improvements to Project 248, Campus Drive to fund the project.
Transfer $80,000 from Project 701, Furniture and Equipment to Project 225, Campus Wide Electronic Locks. The safety and security of the children is of paramount importance in the Child Development Center. Through the De Anza campus budget process the Child Development Center received an allocation of $80,000 in Furniture, Fixture and Equipment dollars to replace the current lock system. This request moves these already allocated dollars over to Project 225, Campus Wide Electronic Locks. In doing so, the Child Development Center will have a more secure and sophisticated system tied to the proposed campus wide system. This is preferable than having a stand-alone system for the Child Development Center.
Transfer $2,000,000 from Project 711, Desktops to Project 404, New District Offices to fund the project.  Please reference District Central Services BT#16.
Foothill Budget Transfer #45 includes the following actions:
Transfer $1,400,000 from Project 199, Foothill Program Contingency to Project 121, Library & ISC to fund the project.
Transfer $120,000 from Project 135, Utility and Infrastructure to Project 162, Parking and Circulation to fund the project.
Transfer $2,000,000 from Project 611, Desktops to Project 404, New District Offices to fund the project. Please reference District/Central Services BT #16.
District/Central Services Budget Transfer #16 includes the following actions:
Create new Project 404, New District Offices
Transfer $2,000,000 from Project 611, Desktops (please reference FH BT #45) and $2,000,000 from Project 711, Desktops (please reference DA BT #43) to fund District/Central Services Project 404, New District Offices. Total transferred to Project 404 is $4,000,000.
Submitted by:
Charles Allen
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Bernata Slater, Tom Armstrong and Donna Jones-Dulin
Is backup provided?
Yes
